About

LearnEDFM in a nutshell.

  • Naturally fractured rocks

    Much of the world’s water and energy resources are located in naturally fractured reservoirs within the earth’s crust. Understanding the dynamics of such reservoirs in terms of flow and transport is crucial to successful application of geothermal energy production in the future.

  • An novel numerical method

    Simulation of flow and transport through fractured porous media is challenging due to the high permeability contrast between the fractures and the surrounding rock matrix. The embedded discrete fracture model (EDFM), which treat fracture and matrix in two separate computational domains is a promising new technique in modelling.

  • Coupled flow and transport

    The governing equations of single phase flow and transport (including diffusion and advection) are discretized using a finite volume scheme. Separate computational domains are employed for fracture and matrix which leads to a coupled system of equations to be solved. An efficient coupling strategy is applied for numerical performance of the model.

  • Live results

    Thanks to the implementation in MATLAB, the simulations' results can be viewed directly and in real-time. A simple input file structure allows for easy modifications to adjust everything to your needs immediately!

  • Get
    LearnEDFM
    today!

Features

LearnEDFM describes the coupled processes connected to fluid flow and transport in the fractured subsurface. We use the embedded discrete fracture model leading to a system of partial differential equations and solve these systems with MATLAB. LearnEDFM comes with the following key features:

  • 2D vectorized MATLAB implementation

  • Single phase darcy flow

  • Tracer transport (advection + diffusion)

  • Comprehensive user manual

Whether you're a student getting a first glimpse modeling naturally fractured reservoirs or a professional researcher looking for a new simulation tool LearnEDFM might be the perfect starting point for you!

License

We wan't to provide you with the freedom to use and modify the code, but care about sharing with the community. Therefore the LearnEDFM source code is released under the GNU General Public License (GPL) v3. The GNU GPL v3 is a copyleft license that requires anyone who distributes the source code or a derivative work to make the source available under the same terms.

Contributors

Gunnar Jansen

Lead Developer

Gunnar is a PhD student focussing on geothermal energy at the universtiy of Neuchâtel. The main focus of his research the development of numerical tools to gain a better understanding of the processes involved in the subsurface. The models are based on coupled processes from fluid dynamics, solid mechanics and heat transport. Further research interests include geothermal resources, numerical methods and the earthquake cycle.

Pressure validation

To validate the model a test case first presented by (Hajibeygi et al., 2011) is used. The test case consists of two perpendicular intersecting fractures in the middle of a square domain. EDFM and reference solution show excellent agreement.

Fracture permeability constrast

Influence of the permeability contrast between fracture & matrix is studied in this example. We compute pressure and transport solutions for the cross shaped fracture test case. Shown here is the pressure distribution. The test case also deals with the transport solution of the coupled problem.

Complex fracture network

Complex fracture network test case including gravity effects. For a complete discription of this example please refer to the user manual. Shown here is the tracer concentration after 14h simulation.
